properties.chatter: The latest from the Heavy Restaurant Group, the people behind the Purple Cafe and Wine bars and neighborhood spots like Meet the Moon. Its latest, north of Gas Works Park, is a casual Mexican bar restaurant, though it won't resemble the same company's popular mescal spot Barrio on Capitol Hill. A dozen different tacos, from wild boar meatballs to lamb belly "carnitas," are featured, along with Mexican comfort food with little Latin tweaks. There are beers from Honduras, Costa Rica and Guatemala. Like at Barrio, Pablo y Pablo also boasts a big agave spirits list, around 70 different mescals and tequilas. The 2,500-square-foot restaurant seats 70 inside and 30 out on the patio.

Started in Kyoto, Japan, and expanded with two locations in California before opening on Capitol Hill in July. The owners saw a growing ramen market in the Seattle area, a spokeswoman said. Its Tentenyu Chashu ramen is supersized with 8 pork slices. There's also a vegetarian ramen option.
Another new ramen spot.

All the favorites, from spring rolls to its pho-ramen hybrid, are offered. This new Ba Bar will double as a test kitchen; expect banh mis, egg noodles and other new dishes to be launched there before you see them at the Capitol Hill or South Lake Union branches.
Ravenna Alehouse is now Flying Boots & Wings, the same folks behind the popular chicken-wing joint in Tacoma
A wood-fire restaurant in Phinney Ridge from chef Mark Schroder, former chef de cuisine at Trove.

Arguably the most popular lunch spot on the Amazon campus now, from the folks behind 99 Park Restaurant in Bellevue. The menu is contemporary American cuisine, with seafood, lamb tartare and Wagyu beef burgers.
Expansion of Kirkland-based macaron sweet treats on the Amazon campus.
Relocated, expect an expanded and more ambitious dinner menu now that there's a bigger kitchen to play with.
A western themed burger-and-shake joint that's more Roy Rogers than Jesse James. Part Austin roadhouse, part saloon, is how the owners described it.

A walk-up window inside Rachel's Ginger Beer at U Village, similar to the setup of other Rachel's bars around town. Like much of Mark Fuller's fare, the food has Hawaiian and Asian tweaks: fried chicken sandwiches are served on King's sweet buns and topped with daikon pickles, and the mac and cheese gets spiced up with Korean chiles. The limited menu consists of just three sandwiches, two salads and four sides.

Comfort food spanning east and west, from loco moco and chow mein to burgers and pork chops. The owner is also opening a pool hall and bar next to this Newport Hills restaurant by the end of the year.
Purchased by some bartenders and other industry peeps. But don't expect any major overhaul with the food-and-drink menu until next year.
Teriyaki, katsu, ramen and yakisoba, but its Instagram-friendly flower pot ice cream seems to get all the love.
Open in the new MarketFront building at Pike Place Market. You can watch them make chocolate behind the glass window. There's also pastries and an espresso bar.
New MarketFront building
New MarketFront building
New MarketFront building
Paleo food and craft cocktails with chef Seamus Platt of Mollusk and Girin heading the kitchen.
Seafood retaurant from the couple behind The Pike Brewing Company.
Mollusk brewery in South Lake Union is rebranding as Dexter Brewhouse: new pub food menu, same beer.
236 seats and a view of Lake Washington in the Hyatt Regency in Renton. The hotel restaurant focuses on pan-Asian cuisine.
Escargot 10 different ways, a Vietnamese delicacy that never became mainstream. This noodle house in the Chinatown International District is the latest to give escargot a go.

properties.address: 7119 Martin Luther King Jr Way S.
properties.chatter: Sandwich shop with 17 different banh mis from pate to grilled pork. The grand-opening special: buy five banh mi, get one free.
Another Vietnamese restaurant, focusing on pho and vermicelli noodles and for brunch, beef stew and chicken congee.
The popular food truck now has a brick-and-mortar in West Seattle with an expanded menu and even beer.
A bit more ambitious than your usual greasy spoon with wild-caught coho and jambalaya on the menu.
Wings and a veggie sandwich are on the menu, but it should be obvious what to order here.

CMB, short for Cheese Meats Bread, opens inside the Uwajimaya food court, from the same owner behind 8oz Burger & Co on Capitol Hill and in Ballard. The kitchen toyed with different grilled-cheese combos before settling on a five-cheese blend of Beecher's flagship white cheddar, buffalo mozzarella, mild cheddar, fontina and muenster.
Great State's fourth location.
The new walk-up window inside Bar Sue, the underrated whiskey bar on Capitol Hill. It hawks tacos, tortas and nachos.
Opens inside Ballard Liquor Store, serving $2 tacos and other Mexican fare.
An eclectic menu of seafood and pizza, and like the bar it replaced, Sixgill, also has a stellar draft list.
Big, cheap portions for the college crowd.
From the same folks behind Analog Coffee, a short and simple breakfast-and-lunch menu (frittata to smoked trout).
Inside Beer Star in White Center, CTO is food inspired by Chinese-American greasy spoons.
Li'l Woody's is open inside Beer Star in White Center
There's pizza again in the old Pizzeria Gabbiano spot in Pioneer Square but under different ownership: RPM, short for Revolution Pizza Music.
What's a new-restaurants list without another poke opening?
A simple “gins & tins” menu of mostly cheeses, charcuteries and tin snacks such as octopus and sardines. Drinks are mostly Spanish-style gin-and-tonic cocktails.
